reviewText: Although the video and audio on this DVD is par with a VHS tape, reflecting 1970s TV movie production values, the story of a Magi, along with his Servant in search of the Messiah to bring Him a gift, will touch the most hardened heart. You might catch this on Christian TV sometime around Easter, but don't miss it. Martin Sheen and Alan Arkin are brilliant. Look for Charlie Sheen and other rising and established stars in cameo roles.
summary: This film will bring tears, but drives home a message!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film is a little heartwarming drama that the whole family can enjoy. It reminded me that in serving Christ, in my walk with Jesus, I have to remember that it's about relationship and about serving others, and not about me and just my needs. The movie can get a little tedious at times, and there aren't any great special effects like audiences expect these days, but again like I said it's just a nice little heartwarming film with good moral values for the family. It will help you reset and ground yourself. It will force you to re-examine your walk with Him and discover what your true motives are in following Christ.

reviewText: This film is a tradition at my house. There aren't enough good things you could say about it. The acting was inspiring, and the message beautiful. The essential message of the Gospels is worked in to demonstrate the simple, but crucial moral message of the Gospels. You come away realizing that the way the life was lived (both of Jesus and of Artaban), and not the death nor supposed resurrection, is the crucial thing to study and emulate.
summary: Best film for holidays and all year

reviewText: This made-for-TV movie turned out to be much better than I anticipated, thanks to the two main characters, played by top actors, and a very thought-provoking message.This is a fictional Biblical story, but one that leaves one reflecting about ourselves, regarding where our hearts lie, and the importance of helping our fellow man. Martin Sheen plays the "fourth wise man" or fourth Magi who knew about the upcoming birth of The Messiah, like the three who did make it to see baby Jesus in Bethelem.Unfortunately, "Artaban," as he was named, got sidetracked en route. He kept running into people in need and he helped each one by giving them the gifts he was intending for Christ. This went on for years, until he finally meets Jesus, at the cross.He is accompanied by Alan Arkin's pessimistic servant "Orontes," who plays off Sheen's optimistic character with humorous results.To those who are repelled by any Biblical implications, this movie is simply an old-fashioned story more about giving, helping others out who are in need, than anything else....and if that's offensive to you, God help you!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of the best bible related movies I have ever seen. Martin Sheen was outstanding in his performance, and he played his role as a part of the magi wonderfully.The movie really taught how important it was to help others and care for them. It had M.S. making huge sacrifices in order to help other people. Different ways of doing this are like what Jesus taught in the bible. He tried to find Jesus Christ along with the other three wise men, and he brought along three valuable gems to give Jesus. (One was a pearl) But he ended up giving them all away to other people. It was a wonderful illustration on how giving to others and making personal sacrifices for someone else's sake is like doing it for Jesus.And by the way, if you are thinking of getting that cartoon called "The Three Wise Men" just because Martin Sheen is in it, forget it. It has ZERO to do with the story of Jesus, and it has all sorts of witchcraft, introducing cults and magic beliefs. If they wanted to do a movie that involved astrology or dark evil demonic sorcerors, then they should have made that instead of making it into a guise of the birth of Jesus Christ.
summary: Well, it's definitely better than "The Three Wise Men"!

reviewText: A top cast and an outstanding quality story that touches the heart make timeless and timely this TV production shown at Easter in 1985.  The fourth wise man, Artaban, played beautifully by Martin Sheen, discovers at the end of his 33 year journey searching for Jesus, just one step behind, that faith combines works. I cry every time I see the ending.  The opportunities and challenge in Jesus' command to love God and love our neighbor in biblical times are the same today.  Show it to a group and then discuss it.  Be moved to action by this film.
summary: A wise man will be moved to action by this film

reviewText: I gave this movie a 3-star rating.  I did not, not like it.  The acting was good.  The plot was ok.  The idea was worth while.  The movie had no bones...until the end...(I won't give the last few scenes away in case someone else views the whole thing through like my wife and I did.Martin Sheen is usually a great actor.  But he just couldn't carry off this roll.  I don't think he believed enough of what he tried to portray.  The movie finally did it in the last scenes.So, if you want the heart and soul of this movie; watch the first 5 or 10 minutes to set up the plot, then the last 30 to 60 seconds to get the meat.
summary: Aaahhh... I could have done without it....

reviewText: Based on the novel by Henry van Dyke, 'The Story of the Other Wise Man', it is the story of Artaban, a Magi and medical doctor who leaves his practice and wealth behind to find the King of Kings he believes has been born in Jerusalem. His father assigns his servant Orontes to go along and protect Artaban and promises to set him free when he returns safely. Artaban brings three precious and valuable gifts to present this new King. Pursuing every lead they find, they are always just missing Jesus at every turn. Their journey lasts 33 years culminating on Easter Sunday. Though fiction, it incorporates many Biblical facts and is a fascinating tale of one man's search for meaning in life and how that changes him along the way. Arkin also does a great job as the reluctant, humorous servant more interested in returning home and getting his freedom than finding this Messiah. Although not a big budget film, the acting is good and the story is very meaningful. [...]

reviewText: The premise to the story sounds interesting, and the pairing of Arkin and Sheen had promise, but for me this film falls flat, though the ending is touching. It has a good message but is just a little too cliched and the acting is a little too flat.  Plus, there is the suggestion of some humor in the telling, but I couldnt really see any, it seems to me as stultified as any of the conventional takes on 'The Greatest Story Ever Told'.

reviewText: While many families watch "A Christmas Carol" or "It's a Wonderful Life" together every year as a Christmas tradition, my family watches this amazing 72 minute version of a fictional Biblical account of "The Fourth Wise Man".  The film was made in the mid-80's with an in-his-prime Martin Sheen in the title role as Artaban, a magi who misses the caravan that went to worship the baby Jesus, and spends the rest of his life trying to find him so he can offer his praise and follow him.  Alan Arkin plays Artaban's hapless servant Orestes, and is by turns very funny and moving.  Great support is lent by Ralph Bellamy, Eileen Brennan, Richard Libertini.  Look for uncredited cameos by both Sheen's son Charlie, and Arkin's son Adam, both in one of their first film appearances.  A fun and poignant Christmas story that is religious in theme without feeling too overly-reverent or preachy.
summary: Fantastic version of a little known Christmas classic
